text: Brown Chapel in Selma's where we started
our journey the same place the activists
left from in 1965 as they set out on
their march to Montgomery they only got
to the bridge out of town and they were
confronted by police
we met the youngest person he was there
that day this was the most traumatic
experience of my life the leaders of
that March they were asked to turn the
marches around
however they refused and after they
refused on racism unleashed its
brutality upon us tear gas had begun to
burst in the air people were being
beamed down with billy clubs as if they
weren't even human beings
all week we weren't just looking back
but also the issues that remain in this
area there's still de facto segregation
in schools he is what happened to one
black parent we met who sent her
daughter to an all-white private school
kids spray-painted in the yard go back
home and they created a website in the
Facebook page and there is graffiti
spray-painted of a Shanaya being hung
from a tree that said you know in okay
is a homosexual I mean there was just
all this like negative stuff and I'm
like this is all brewing underneath
education officials admitted there were
problems but said there was little that
could be done to bring about true
integration here the landscapes in
Alabama are beautiful the people
welcoming but debates about race rage on
the state has one of the highest rates
in the country for putting people in
prison african-americans told us they
feel they're targeted by the police the
authorities insist that's not the case
we met those affected when this very
week Alabama hit the headlines for
another rights issue the state's Chief
Justice has just pushed through a ban on
gay marriage here when people look back
on this issue perhaps in 50 years time
you stand by the decision you've made
now and you'll come out on the right
side of history
absolutely absolutely it will prove to
be the right side of history because
that's the way civilizations prosper
we've seen this week this clearly much
to be resolved in terms of race with
many african-americans still asking how
long will it take
not long Martin Luther King told the
crowds here in 1965 because the arc of
the moral universe is long he said but
it bends towards justice
